review_title: A great job with SubPar Equipment
pros: Great pay overall. Pays the bills. Benefits package is interesting but totally worth it. Supervisory attitude is second to none that I've ever worked under. The job goes on so there is really no need to worry too much about stressing too much.
cons: Truck equipment quality seriously lacks. Overall compared to other, bigger companies it's okay. If you don't like to follow rules, or can't stand routine or consistency, this job is not for you. Every day is the same but totally different than any other day.

review_title: Not viewed as valuable if not a driver
pros: Good insurance and 401k. Good vacation time
cons: 5 years with the company and an exceeds expectations on my last review (which is very hard to get) and couldn’t even get an exit interview with my HR manager. She was there that day ironically. This solidified that I was leaving for all the right reasons. I went to many other republics and this seems to be a divisional issue opposed to a company wide issue. Difficult to get the support I needed from management to do my job properly. Certain drivers get favoritism and it’s not decided on their work ethic, unfortunately this made it hard to get customers recovered. This would make it appear to my team that I was showing favoritism, when I wasn’t able to get support from management to back me up and hold these drivers accountable.

review_title: It’ll seem great at first. After 6 months you’ll be running
pros: Health insurance is pretty good
cons: The business unit that I worked out of was literally ran by 2 supervisors who had little to no sales experience. Young and inexperienced “yes men” who will not stand up for what is right. I lost more customers than I could sign due to drivers just flat out refusing to do their jobs. It’s pretty bad when their own employees are canceling their own trash and recycling services because the company couldn’t even provide them consistent service. Yes, their own employees are canceling their services with the company they work for because they’re not getting the service they’re paying for….need I say more? As a sales rep here this is what you will be forced to sell. Forced to look at customers and tell them “we’re not the low cost provider because we’re a PREMIUM service” knowing that there’s a slim to none chance that Republic Services will even provide the service. You’ll be inundated with constant phone calls from the moment you sign a customer with complaints. NON STOP. The company is a churn and burn. Complaints? Oh well “move on to the next” I have never in my life worked for a company that just genuinely does not care about their customers or their employees.

pros: Opportunity for growth throughout the US.

review_title: You will be screamed at for 8 hours straight every day.
pros: The job is fully remote.
cons:
You will be screamed at non-stop by customers who aren't getting their trash services that they pay for. Management will blame every bad call on you instead of the customer who is calling in being abusive. If you get a bad survey score from a customer or the customer issues a complaint it is always your fault even if the customer is doing it maliciously. They say we need to help the customer better yet the company severely limits what we can do to help the customer.

If a customer demands a supervisor and we transfer to the Relationship Desk so they can speak with one then we get flagged for "work avoidance". We're told we're supposed to deescalate and handle that, but we aren't paid to do that. That's what the RD is for but it's bad if we transfer. If we issue credits they'll flag us for issuing too many credits but if we don't issue a credit and the customer complains then we're at fault.

You will not get any holidays off unless you use your PTO and you won't get that because they never approve PTO. You will almost always be denied and if you don't take your PTO then you lose it. Management took away holidays claiming it was based off of employee feedback yet literally no employee asked for it. It's a thinly veiled justification for not paying out PTO since we never get approved for it off and we lose it. 

The pay is slightly better than most other call centers but for the amount of abuse and the call volume makes it nowhere near enough compensation. Call volume is sometimes so high customers are waiting for an hour and the first thing they do is yell at the innocent agent taking the call. Republic Services absolutely refuses to hire enough people and the call volume is all our fault despite the fact these customers are calling in solely because Republic Services did not service them.

Management tries to make it sound like they aren't blaming us by periodically holding raffles for prizes. These raffles are for all the agents so your likelihood to win anything is extremely low and most of the prizes are a "ride-along in a garbage truck". No one wants that. We want more money for the abuse we have to take.

If you say you're tired of being screamed at the only response you will get is "don't let it get to you" or "push those bad vibes away". It's literally no help. It's like telling a depressed person to " just be happy".

Management expects you to show empathy to customers while refusing to show any to you. 

They recently did a "customer zeal" push. This customer zeal literally blamed all call center agents for bad calls instead of addressing the root of problem which is the operations team not picking up garbage. They're untouchable, though, since they're unionized so we get the blame. 

The yearly raises are laughable. Doesn't even come close to matching inflation and if you get any bad occurrences you can't get a raise. And guess what? Everything I said above results in an occurrence.

pros:
Great pay
Work from home
The job is easy, just really awful
Coworkers are great
Equipment provided
There's lots of ladders to climb in any direction, anywhere in the company.
cons:
Policies are strict and zero tolerance. While some supervisors will work with you in one off situations, others will fire you no questions asked.
Those same supervisors will encourage you to get FMLA for medical exemptions, then bully you out of using it or find a loophole to fire you for it.
You need a doctor's note to provide to HR to clock out and use the restroom. They will fire you if you go pee without one. 
PTO is use it or lose it within the same calendar year, it's inevitable that you will lose a chunk every year. Even what you accrued in December.
It's a call center, you should know up front most people who call are already mad. It's a given. You don't get a breather. The call ends, another starts and there is no reset. Hopefully the previous caller wasn't that mean.

review_title: Overall good company that could use some sales revamps
pros:
-Great Benefits, 401k, Vacation, PTO
-Reasonable Base Salary + good potential commission earnings
-Nationwide career opportunities (can move up the ladder quickly if willing to move)
-Stable long-term employment
-Vast resources
cons:
Runs very lean which leaves little room to adapt to issues quickly operationally. This creates many calls and a lot of work for sales which they can little effect. It becomes challenging to sell if 90% of your time is addressing issues due to service... not all the time but often enough depending on your area and current labor challenges with drivers in 2021.
From a sales standpoint, you are judged on salesforce effort numbers. (calls, proposals, emails, meetings) with no room for not hitting the number for any reason. This is regardless of whether you are actually performing new business or retention-wise. Creates an environment with lots of inaccurate data logging so upper management feels good while wasting thousands of hours of productivity throughout the field.
Top performers will do well here but earnings can be dramatically limited by per deal commission caps. So if you are one of the best pushing for more all the time is self-defeating. The more you sell the more base work you'll have in this role. At the same time selling 100k deal may pay you the same as someone else who sells a 15k deal.

review_title: This workplace disregards the safety and wellbeing of their employees and exploits labor.
pros: You get to work your tail off for $11.5 while being poorly protected from the quality of air in the workplace as well as from Covid-19.
cons:
If you are hired as a temp they'll work you a mandatory sixty hours a week, lie to you about having every other Saturday off, intimidate you to keep up productivity, and wear you out until they can fire you for attendance. There is a lack of protection against Covid-19; bathrooms and breakroom are cleaned infrequently and you're given a cheap dust mask with no tight seal, which also doesn’t help with the poor air quality in the facility. I wasn’t given rubber gloves for under my work gloves like at my previous recycling job, before the pandemic. There is low pay and high expectations and the supervisors lack communication skills or knowledge on workplace safety.
I tried to contact Republic Services ethics team two months ago due to a situation with a coworker that wasn't feeling well that made me feel concerned for her safety as well as the rest of the employees. I was told my written statement could get the lead supervisor at Leadpoint fired (there are two companies operating together in this building,) given this situation I witnessed and other concerns. I'm assuming this supervisor is still working there due to the lack of response from the ethics team. He would creepily touch my lower back when I started working there, so I would suggest women avoid this workplace.

pros: I’m employed, compared to a lot of people affected by the virus; hours are great at least; I’ve made some friends
cons: You get extra work on your plate unless you’re unionized and even then they’ll try it unless you speak up (was even assigned extra responsibilities [outside of my role] without any mention in pay raise); work from home is pick and choose (even if your job can easily be done from home) and if you’re still there, you’re picking up everyone else’s work; I can’t ask another fellow ops clerk for help because they’re always “busy” but I’m expected to reciprocate; the paper ticket system is so antiquated it takes too much time especially when we don’t charge the customer for the time spent so it ends up as more cheap labor; don't promote from within, would rather hire externally bc its cheaper so you’re stuck in your position; this work is excruciatingly mind-numbing; would have never gotten a pay raise without unionizing; you won’t get any positive feedback, recognition, nothing until you mess up; LACK OF DIVERSITY, with all this racism flying around I’ve received no checking in, I’ve had an upper management employee touch my hair on various occasions (doubt HR would know how to handle it); too much bureaucracy, but that’s every job; sorry not sorry but if people refuse to get vaccinated then send me home to work, why am I risking my safety for selfish people???

pros: Republic is the first place I have ever worked where I feel truly appreciated and comfortable being who I truly am. Management is always available to talk to you about anything and everything. They say they care about their employees and I think they make an honest effort to actively show that through their actions. Also, tons of transparency about the company health and finances. I appreciate being treated as a valuable team member here and that I feel I am always listened to.
cons: My biggest thing here is the lack of upward mobility in the tech department. I know people who have been waiting years to get an offer to be promoted, requested interest in being promoted and then nothing happens. They are allowed to do extra work to get the experience but they are still working under their previous position pay and title. I know they are trying to address this, which is great, but management needs to be actively engaging in these steps and conversations instead of making the employee put forth all the effort with no results. I am not hopeless that this will change, but its my biggest con right now.

pros: Hello, I would like to say that I am very proud to work for Republic Services and my upper management . Mr. Jamie Amick, Jimmy Torrey, Allison Sheaves, David Holt,Mrs. Diane, Rodney, and Doug. I recently had an accident and they were very supportive and encouraging to the matter. I've been with the company almost 20 years and I must say that I am very proud to work for them and Republic. They advised me and counseled me, giving me advice after coming back from my suspension. I was upset with myself and very apologetic because they know how hard I work and give it my all. Understanding that safety is first and foremost. I would like to thank these outstanding personnel for continuing to believe in me and for allowing to still have my job and provide for my family and pay for my education towards getting my degree. I felt compelled to share my story and give them the gratification that they all deserve.
cons: There are no downsides that I can think of at this point, because the hard work and instruction that they provide and the level of stress and concern that is placed on Safety everyday is warranted. pros: A small and relaxed working environment. Although there are departmental conflicts, within each department is a "family" who values and respects their counterparts. For the most part, management is helpful, competent, and deserving of their positions. Area, Regional, and Corporate Management is dedicated to making the best company possible. There are many times that you will be proud to work there due to customer satisfaction, communtiy involvement, and service standards.
cons: The animosity between departments creates a tense workplace. There are certain managers who are legends in their own mind and use unprofessional actions, lies, and bad-mouthing other depts/managers to enhance their own self image. These managers, specifically one who likes to hear himself talk, are not very well-liked in the company due to their unprofessional standards, failing departments, and lack of managerial skills. Cutting down other employees and using unapplicable mottos does not constitute effective managing and employee inspiration. There are some departments within the division that are over-worked and are poorly paid while another department is seemingly idle all day and receives regular recognition for other peoples' work. The lack of team spirit and work ethic of some people will frustrate you. As an employee for many years, it is disheartening to see the downward direction of the division in recent times.

review_title: The Charlotte Center is managed POORLY
pros: The pay and benefits are decent. The trainers are great! The actual building is nice. There is free coffee, tea, and fruit available everyday. The company is growing fast, so plenty of growth opportunities within the call center.
cons: The company is growing, leaving lots of cracks in the foundation to cause major problems. Management is very poor. Some act like they care about their employees, but they don’t, while others don’t even bother to act. Too many false promises. Nobody is on the same page, which leads to a lot of misinformation, and if you mess up based on the misinformation you received from someone higher up, you’re still to blame. They’ll build you up to believe the job is great, but in reality, it’s hard to tolerate even being there. They took 12 paid hours from me and they switched my schedule up the Friday before it went into effect. They’ll know that they made a mistake, wait for you to realize it, then basically say, “Sorry, we’ll do better next time, but you just have to deal with it.” Save yourself the frustration and don’t apply.

review_title: Room for advancement, but culture needs changing
pros:
-Company has great benefits (401k match, generous PTO) 
-Lot of opportunity for advancement
-Room to make a lot of changes and have a huge impact
-Company has some gem employees that really make working for the company worth it
cons:
-The culture is painfully difficult. They work you really long hours without a thank you.
-From my business unit specifically, a very authoritarian culture. They're cut-throat,  unforgiving, and hard to please. Except for the drivers, they don't train you well and just expect you to know everything. 
-Inconsistency between departments. They don't communicate well. Everybody is against each other. Ops is against sales, sales is against ops,
-The processes are slow, outdated, and not maintained. Nobody really asks why we are doing it, they just do it because it's been done before.  
-Technology is outdated. 
-Hiring process is redundant at the BU level, and leads to us losing quality talent because it takes so long to hire drivers and technicians.
-Company does not value technicians. 
-The customer service center doesn't understand the impact of their actions on drivers and the entire business unit. They make our jobs 100x harder than it has to be.
-Leadership not attune to feedback. We have an annual engagement survey, but nothing ever gets done with it.

pros: Majority of BU co-workers were great to work with daily.  Health and dental. Monthly bonus structure with quarterly bonus as well. Management that will listen and work with you on dealing with account issues, are a godsend. Consistently moving forward with innovation and ideas for an ever changing industry.
cons:
Low ball base pay scale for what job entails. 
Consistent issues with Customer Resource Centers. Including extreme wait times for already angry customers, little training and understanding of business unit procedures and geographic differences in business unit pricing, the ability to quote and close sales on accounts that will wind up in your book of business without you ever knowing and will not get even partial credit, and the ability to close an account without consulting the BU or the Rep regarding agreements.
Loss of PTO days for hourly employees if BU closes during weather related events. 
The absolute reliance on a database copyrighted during the Reagan Administration. 
Mountains of paperwork and few backup personnel in positions that are needed for paperwork signatures or immediate database entry. 
The occasional “blue flu” from the drivers. 
Hiring can be dicey. Employees can be moved to "upper ladder" jobs that they may not be remotely prepared to handle.

cons: Listed in the above category

pros: Great industry. Lots of hardworking quality employees. Company attempting to upgrade tools. Committed  to safety.  Local customer service and maint teams. They are trying!  Decent pay/benefits.  Occasional perks like special events/ contests.  Dedicated empathetic front line mgmt.  Best company in industry until recently.
cons: Way too much time spent fixing billing and service issues. Training does not reflect real world scenarios.  Turnover is terrible. New pricing tool bad for existing customers. Too many upper mgmt types hired from outside the industry.  Be proud of where we came from and develop your talent.  RATE INCREASES ARE RUINING CO REPUTATION.  20% increases per year get noticed.  Small competitors with poor service can compete due to rate increases alone.  Front line mgmt and employees generally don't trust upper mgmt and have poor work/family balance.

review_title: The Veiw From An Ops Supervisor
pros: Republic has come together in time of need like no other company I have ever worked for. I love the level of onboard training the drivers and supervisors get coming in the door. I wish that would encompass shop supervisors and techs as well. I also love the engagement that is encouraged from corporate down but wish more managers were on board with it and understood that benefits. I can't champion enough the Supervisor Onboarding class. It seems like it would be to much before you get there and then you realize that two weeks is barely enough. More time could be had and I think supervisors form other areas (maintenance, landfill etc) could benefit greatly.
cons: Inconsistent management, policy directive, maintenance procedures, supervisor development, and the ability or lack there of to coach/CA (document) a bad, infectious, cancerous employee out the door. And not reward that behavior with another transfer, more pay and relocation package to fill a void. When as a supervisor hired from out of state I wasn't even offered a weekend stay in my transition. I am not saying this to be bitter I promise. But it doesn't give a good the other employees the correct image of how to conduct themselves.

pros: Friendly, great benefits, competitive pay, great employee relationship, safe, state of the art equipment
cons: None so far, time will tell

job_title: Legal Assistant/Paralegal in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Good pay and flexibility for students. Good temp job.

review_title: Sorting - Great management, poor working conditions
job_title: Sorter in Inver Grove Heights, MN
pros: Managers care about their employees, we stretched before our shift and the manager was very nice/understanding. Two 15 min. breaks as well as a 30 min. break were nice as well. Protection in terms of clothing, hard hats, footwear, hearing, and hands/arms were taken seriously with protection options being readily available.
cons: Excessive heat (although heat sickness comes fast for me), the only source of cool air being the fans blowing towards our direction from 15-20 ft. away and the break room. Obviously the smell, since working in a recycling sorting facility comes with handling loads of garbage. Also we'd have to stop the operation at some points to leave our sorting stations and climb down latters to the main floor and collect/sweep up garbage/recyclable materials that fell from the conveyors. The heat and smell from being down there, sweeping, was almost unbearable. And kicking up industrial dust bunnies by sweeping, without a dust mask wasn't healthy by any means. Lastly, compared to other sorting facilities, the building seemed outdated.

pros: Nice people to work with
cons: Environment can be disorganized at times

job_title: Front Load Driver in Knoxville, TN
pros: Pay is "OK", Needs to be more though. Benefits are "OK", Nothing great.
cons: Prepare for the end of your personal life, I get up at 1am and get home at 5-6pm. They constantly look to "wright you up" over any little thing they can find. I've been here less than a year and have seen more wright up's, 3 day suspension's, And people getting fired than I have in my entire working life. Trucks don't get repaired like they should. If it can be "patched up" instead of downing the truck and spending the money to fix it right, That's what they will do. I've been told the less they spend on repairing trucks the bigger the bonus management will get. Of course I can't prove this but I can say they don't like to spend money the trucks, I'm in my mid 40's and this is the worst truck I have ever been in. They'll preach safety one minute, Then give you a day and half worth of work and expect you to get it done, Safely, In one day. You have to run long, Hard hours and if you get into an accident you could loose your job depending on how bad it was. Nobody in management has ever told me "Good Job, Thanks, I Appreciate You", Nothing, Ever. They usually act like your bothering them if they have speak to you. Overall this is the worst place I have ever worked.

pros: There are no pros to working here.

pros: It is a good stable company.  Most of the people who work at it care.  The company cares about its people.  They provide us with the right equipment to get the job done.   I enjoy coming to work most of the time.

These pricing practices are the reason I do not like to tell people where I work so I do not get yelled at because their rates are so high.  Sales compensation is out of whack compared to what we sell.  The CRC issues are much worse than is getting reported back to corporate.  We are losing business because of them but no one wants the truth about it.  It is just easier to complain to the BU's that they are not selling without fixing the true issue at hand. pros: Great company and culture. Nice salary for the waste industry.
cons: Commissions can be low if deals fall under target price. Extra fee's can become a roadblock for some customers.

pros:
Weekly pay check
Benefits are great
The company overall is a great company.  
If you need sales experience this isn't a bad job.  Just know it gets better after you leave.
cons:
In my office (BU), no one in leadership cares beyond themselves.  They have little to no trust in the sales department.  Encouraged to fudge activity numbers so they look good.
I contacted HR 3 different times about the harassment of our sales manager to the sales team and didn't receive any response.  That's when I had to leave.
No communication between operations, billing and sales.  Which makes the customer experience tough.
Not open to new ideas.  When our sales group present ways to improve communications they were shut down immediately.  
Constant garbage pick up misses and deliveries not on time make sales job hard.  We receive charge backs when customers cancel even if its because our operations doesn't deliver a can or pick up.  Things out of our control.
Our office building itself is gross.  Its dirty, old tech, ceiling caving in, broken chairs, no office supplies, no windows and awful smell.
You are expected to work during vacations and other paid time off.

pros: Environmentally responsible, opportunity to advance your career for those who want to grow with the company. Training program for operations supervisors and ops mgr's have improved greatly over the last year.
cons: 1) Truck replacements - if you have 50 trucks that are do to be replaced this year, you might get 15 trucks if your lucky. Division moral among drivers and mechanics dwindles.  2) our business is simple, we pick the trash up safely and efficiently. In the field, new reports have to be filed, new reports come out to look at, conference call after conference call, meeting after meeting. 3) We talk about wanting operations supervisors / mgr's to have more home time, but we put more and more on their plates. 4) We continue to move jobs out of the local level and to corporate offices. 5) We are too top heavy with corporate management. 6) WM does something, we follow. Why aren't we LEADING instead of following their moves? 7) customers leave after realizing they have been overpaying significantly on their services compared to our competitors.

pros: Great place to work at.
cons: Long hours on the job.

pros:
Strong company with locations in most of the US.  Area structure provides support to local teams.

Good 401(k) plan.

Good choices on health benefits although pricey for the size of the company compared to other companies.

Constant effort in maintaining good employee engagement.

Always looking for ways to improve.
cons:
It is nearly impossible to disconnect when on vacation.  Work/life balance can be a challenge, yet if you don’t use your PTO hours you lose them at the end of the year.  Some employees put in for PTO but end up working from home or vacation.

Field employees are viewed almost as subpar by corporate employees making it very difficult for field employees to transfer/promote to a corporate role.  

The corporate teams making changes/implementations don’t always understand how they are impacting the field. 

Annual merit increases are 2% on average making it a difficult message to communicate to your hourly employees who are receiving just cents per hour increases. 

Some facilities are very old and in dire need of repair.

Very political environment.

job_title: Inside Sales Representative in Chandler, AZ
pros: There is room to grow in the company if you can meet all your metrics. Free coffee
cons: There are a lot of changes taking place currently and it's becoming an environment that is not fun to work in anymore. Every year employee metrics go up and management makes it almost impossible to meet all of them. This role should be very fun and easy to be successful in but some of the other employees make it near impossible to enjoy due to all the unnecessary drama. If you just graduated college and are looking to work in a fun mature environment, this is not the place you want to be. You get two 15 minute breaks and one 45 minute lunch, if you get out of your desk out of that hour and fifteen minutes, you can kiss your perfect metrics good bye.

review_title: My experience has been better than what I expected
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Chandler, AZ
pros: I'm currently part of one of the new classes of temps and I just finished my first week here. Honestly, I initially was just taking on this job as a summer job to quit when I go back to college in the fall, but I found this place to be very pleasant to work at. On the first day, I was wondering what koolaid the employees and management were drinking to be so passionate about working there. Coming in as a temp, I was expecting to be treated like just a number or meat in a blender; however, that was not the experience I felt at all. They really do want us to succeed and be happy, of course, our customers ultimately. Sure, they do have strict rules, but they're in place for a reason, which I can respect. It all comes down to being considerate to others. I probably won't be able to work here full-time during the school year, but it's definitely a great place to work, which is rare in today's cutthroat economy.
cons: None so far, I haven't been here long enough. I just hope they can offer part-time opportunities during the school year.

pros: The Company is mature but could be much more profitable.
cons: Inconsistencies throughout the three Regions and Corporate with regards to market stratization, poor follow-up on improvement recommendations, slow to react to bids and acquisitions which has cost them nemerous opportunities due to red-tape.  They could have purchased Progressive Waste which had $2+Billion in annual revenues, but they dragged their feet and let Waste Connections buy them.  This has been a very successful acquisitions for Waste Connections.  Human Resources has a stronghold on the Regions which inhibits their abilities to manage their people and causes unneccessary delays in hiring new personnel.  These delays have resulted in numerous qualified Professionals accepting positions at other Comanies. Widespread Nepotism and Management promotions based on friends in the Company and not experience or abilities which has greatly diluted the strenghth of middle and upper management.

job_title: Class B CDL Truck Driver in Anaheim, CA
pros: The pay is ok,and the benefits are not bad. Medical ,Dental and vision are through the union. Dental insurance is not great. People seem friendly. The equipment is ok. Although they seem to be getting in some newer equipment.
cons: I applied for the Roll Off Driver position online and got hired for Roll Off. But,I  have yet to see the inside of a roll off truck. They have me training in a front loader for commercial. The training at Republic Services in Anaheim is not great. Very unorganized group of supervisors that don't seem to have any experience in the waste and recycle business. The supervisors seem lost at times. I came to Republic Services because I thought it was a first class company,only to find out the grass is not greener on the other side. I'm very disappointed with my experience so far.

review_title: Commercial and Industrial Account management.....more like baby sitting
job_title: Account Manager in Commerce City, CO
pros: The pay was above average
cons: You basically apologized all day for the drivers missing pickups, the phone would not stop ringing with people complaining about how bad this service was.  Also billing questions about why their bill would go up by 25% 9 months after signing a 3 year contract.  It's total extortion as they try to hold you to the contract.  It appears that  organized crime hasn't gotten to far away from the garbage business.  Horrible work environment in an office for 10+ hours a day, too hot and then too cold.  Not very friendly employees and the training is horrible.  You will spend weeks doing online training and then 3 days in phoenix only to realize that everything you were taught was completely useless when it came to the performance of the company and it's operations staff.  Way to paperwork heavy too.  Still manually filling out forms and trying to figure out the right codes.  You will get buried in paperwork.

job_title: Billing Coordinator in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: working directly with clients internally and externally
cons: The company lacks communication entirely, this is why a majority of customers leave as well, no one is on the same page. There is no room for growth unless you have a degree (knowledge base or experience doesn't count) or are friends or family of someone already in management  They pay very poorly and the average increase yearly is around $.16 if you are even given one.  You are micro-managed at all times and in all honesty the office atmosphere is that of a kindergarten class.  Everyone blames each other for problems (including management)  instead of working together to fix issues.  If you enjoy gossip, this is definitely the place for you.  And don't forget being talked down to by management as if you are a child being punished.  Respect is not a factor here.   All in all, the Salt Lake City office is summed up as a HUGE stress and has the ability to break a person down both physically and mentally.
